body:
# PROPFIND

For the PROPFIND request, Firefox is very verbose but I don't understand fully:
```
Failed to load â€˜http://localhost:8080/â€™. A ServiceWorker passed a promise to FetchEvent.respondWith() that rejected with â€˜TypeError: NetworkError when attempting to fetch resource.â€™. 

Cross-Origin Request Blocked: The Same Origin Policy disallows reading the remote resource at http://localhost:8080/. (Reason: CORS request did not succeed). Status code: (null).
```

Brave/Chrome reports just
```
PROPFIND http://localhost:8080/ net::ERR_BLOCKED_BY_CLIENT
```

It is possible that the The Same Origin Policy is really the cause but I'm not sure if I can adjust it.

If I run dufs as the WebDAV server in the same directory:

```
dufs --enable-cors
```
the PROPFIND request returns XML, as expected:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
<D:multistatus xmlns:D="DAV:">
<D:response>
<D:href>/</D:href>
<D:propstat>
<D:prop>
<D:displayname></D:displayname>
```
etc.

The log is below. 8080 is rclone, 5000 is dufs.
![image](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/assets/462445/f5240e03-2643-4e8d-8e23-d40bad331749)

Note that dufs does not have anything specified for `Access-Control-Request-Method`.

> As noted in #5078, these headers are included in the Response and I'm wondering if that is the source of the issue:
> 
> ```
> Access-Control-Allow-Origin  | *
> Access-Control-Request-Method | POST, OPTIONS, GET, HEAD
> ```

Webdav requires quite a few special HTTP methods. Here is [the full list](https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/i/7.1?topic=concepts-webdav)


|Method|Specifications|Description|
| --- | --- | --- |
|COPY|WebDAV|Copies the resource.|
|DELETE|HTTP 1.1/WebDAV|Deletes the resource.|
|GET|HTTP 1.1|Gets the contents of the resource.|
|HEAD|HTTP 1.1|Returns the message headers from a message sent to the server.|
|LOCK|WebDAV|Locks the resource.|
|MKCOL|WebDAV|Creates the collection specified.|
|MOVE|WebDAV|Moves the resource.|
|OPTIONS|HTTP 1.1|Performs an option call to the server.|
|POST|HTTP 1.1|Action defined by the server.|
|PROPFIND|WebDAV|Performs a property find on the server.|
|PROPPATCH|WebDAV|Sets or removes properties on the server.|
|PUT|HTTP 1.1/WebDAV|Puts the contents of the resource to the server in the specified location.|
|TRACE|HTTP 1.1|Does a trace call to the server.|
|UNLOCK|WebDAV|Unlocks the resource.|

Rclone doesn't actually use all of these methods though.

According to the [Mozilla docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Request-Method) `Access-Control-Request-Method` is something the client sends the server, not the other way round so I don't know why rclone is sending that.

Try commenting out, or changing this line to see if you can get it to work

https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/668711e43213bc9464c0b25c88621cd987898f08/lib/http/middleware.go#L186

>Try commenting out, or changing this line to see if you can get it to work

Good tip. Unfortunately, that doesn't seem to do it. :'(

![image](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/assets/462445/e07450b4-b4db-42ab-a8c9-10bb5e0b6561)

![image](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/assets/462445/921a43ff-bd7b-4466-b6de-c597f8768014)

Which is confusing considering that a request made from Windows Explorer lists the folder regularly:

![image](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/assets/462445/2fae4c1c-fbe3-4769-aea2-4aadce98c34c)

Obviously it's some combination with the browser. 

In Brave, all of the requests now fail. Chrome reports 

> Cross-origin resource sharing error: Method Disallowed by Preflight response

When using `dufs` as a server, everything works:

![image](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/assets/462445/d634cf81-ee86-4312-9e98-e69fb63016f3)

I also tried adding PROPFIND to the list at line 186 but the results are the same.
> rclone v1.65.0-DEV

The interesting thing is that, when issuing the same requests (GET, PROPFIND) from the REST Client vscode extension, the results are the same: GET works, PROPFIND doesn't.
> RequestError: getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND propfind

But when doing it from THUNDER Client, both work.

ðŸ˜±

So far, it is clear that the browser blocks these requests. 
The errors happen when the requests are issues from JavaScript and Wasm (which, I guess use the same fetch).
The question, however, is why? Why does this happen with rclone but not duf?

> Try commenting out, or changing this line to see if you can get it to work
> 
> https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/668711e43213bc9464c0b25c88621cd987898f08/lib/http/middleware.go#L186

I think this like is wrong...

I think it should be

    w.Header().Add("Access-Control-Allow-Methods", "POST, OPTIONS, GET, HEAD") 

And if you want webdav to work add some extra methods - this should do it.

    w.Header().Add("Access-Control-Allow-Methods", "COPY, DELETE, GET, HEAD, LOCK, MKCOL, MOVE, OPTIONS, POST, PROPFIND, PROPPATCH, PUT, TRACE, UNLOCK") 

Please try both of those!

> Access-Control-Allow-Methods

Yes!!!
I'll try a few variations and report back. Should I submit a pull request with that line modified?

Having both
```go
w.Header().Add("Access-Control-Request-Method", "POST, OPTIONS, GET, HEAD")
w.Header().Add("Access-Control-Allow-Methods", "POST, OPTIONS, GET, HEAD") 
```
doesn't work.
Using
```go
w.Header().Add("Access-Control-Allow-Methods", "COPY, DELETE, GET, HEAD, LOCK, MKCOL, MOVE, OPTIONS, POST, PROPFIND, PROPPATCH, PUT, TRACE, UNLOCK")
```
makes it work!

Apparently the `Access-Control-Request-Method` is a valid header. However, as you've rightfully noted earlier, it is a Request header, and not a Response header: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Request-Method
So I'd confirm that it should probably be removed. There are no changes in behaviour that result from having it there or not.

issue.title: #7444 enable WebDAV methods with CORS

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Fixes #7444

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Enables the HTTP methods used with WebDAV protocol. It allows requests to rclone WebDAV issued from web browsers, which are currently blocked by CORS policy.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

#7444

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-new-feature-or-bug-fix).
- [x] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [ ] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [x] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body:
FYI this is still broken, I'm getting this error in browser console when using the `stat` method of WebDAV (reading a file works but copy file is also broken):
`Request header field depth is not allowed by Access-Control-Allow-Headers in preflight response.`

The issue is there are many headers WebDAV uses, like `depth`, but rclone allows only a few:
https://github.com/alensiljak/rclone/blob/668711e43213bc9464c0b25c88621cd987898f08/lib/http/middleware.go#L187

The WebDAV headers are documented in this RFC, I think just adding the request headers to the line above would fix the issue:
http://www.webdav.org/specs/rfc4918.html#http.headers.for.distributed.authoring

@Anchakor, it may be useful if a new issue is created for this (if not already). I have not yet fully utilised the webdav access due to issues in the client library I'd like to use instead of writing the requests and parsing the responses manually.
@alensiljak what we should be doing is adding the headers and extra methods in `rclone serve webdav` rather than adding them to the global server.

issue.title: WebDAV requests with parameters fail with Serve WebDAV

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
I just ran into this issue after trying PROPFIND with 1.65. 
Technically, this is a follow-up on the `serve webdav` issues. #7444 and #7448. Some other items might also be related.

It was mentioned in the last comment [here](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/7444#issuecomment-1828943189), that the message is `Request header field depth is not allowed by Access-Control-Allow-Headers in preflight response.`
This effectively prevents listing just the requested folder. The PROPFIND request works but it does not receive the Depth parameter, which is sent through the header. This comment contains the links to the WebDAV headers and the line that needs to be modified.

Additionally ,as @ncw mentioned [here](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/7444#issuecomment-1838426670), this should be done in the webdav server, not the global one.

#### The associated forum post URL from `https://forum.rclone.org`

n/a

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

Issuing a PROPFIND request fails if it contains a `depth:1` header.

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

1.65

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)

Win 11, 64-bit

#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)

local drive

#### The command you were trying to run (e.g. `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

rclone serve webdav . --allow-origin "*"

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (e.g. output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)

n/a

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the ðŸ‘ [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

issue.title: Support WebDAV headers with CORS

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Fixes #7492

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Allow WebDAV headers when using CORS. 
WebDAV request parameters are sent through headers.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

It's a follow-up on previous fixes of WebDAV with CORS #7444, #7448. The direct issue is #7492.

repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

Fixes #7492

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Allow WebDAV headers when using CORS.
